VOL. LXVII, NO. 24

Grunett Gets
Nod To Run
Next DSRC
Jeff Granett defeated Dave
Rosewell for the Presidency of
the DSRC by a margin of 131
to 27 in elections held last week.
A dog named Biggie received 22
Votes.
Bob Conti and Mark Janssen
are contending for the DSRC
Vice Presidency in a run off
election this week. Michael
Kilpatrick and David Maltz are
the run off candidates for Treasurer; Bardin Levavy and Doyle
Smith seek the position of Secretary.
Amendments Passed
A series of Constitutional
amendments, designed to authorize the election of house officers in the fall, received more
than the two-thirds majority
necessary for ratification. Neal
Grove, President of the DSRC.
expressed satisfaction with this
result.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, APRIL 26, 1963

Judicial Board
In other DSRC news, Neal
Grove announced that the outgoing officers of the Judical
Board are now accepting applications for positions on next
year's board. An Application consists of a letter giving the student's name and class, his box
and room number, a description of his extracurricular activities, and an explanation of any
relevant previous experience. In
addition, an application must include a statement by the applicant of his conception of the
purpose, importance and ramifications of a student run judicial
system. This statement should
include a discussion of what the
applicant feels to be the proper
relation between the student
judicial system and the administration. Applications should be
placed in box 2009.
The Judicial Board consists of
the DSRC President and Secretary, five members and two alternates. Chairman Grove expressed his conviction that the
judicial system has been effective this year.

Jagendori Wins
Kettering Award
Dr. Andre T. Jagendorf, Associate Professor of Biology, has
been named one of the first ten
recipients of the Charles F.
Kettering Research Awards, it
was announced today in Washington.
The awards, given by the
Charles F. Kettering Foundation
of Dayton, Ohio on recommendation of the National Academy of Sciences — National
Research Council, are intended
to encourage creative research
on photosynthesis and related
problems of biology. The awards
are in the form of unrestricted
research grants in an amount
up to $5,000 per year for an
indefinite period.
Dr. Jagendorf is a leading authority on the process of photosynthesis. He is a graduate of
Cornell University and Yale
University, where he obtained
his Ph.D. in 1951. He was a postdoctoral Merck Fellow at the
University of California at Los
Angeles from 1951 to 1953.
Appointed in 1953
He came to Hopkins in 1953
as an Assistant Professor, and
was named to his present position in 1958. In 1961 he was
named Maryland's "outstanding
young scientist" by the Maryland Academy of Sciences.
In his research on photosynthesis, Dr. Jagendorf has been
able to prepare from the green

plant a free cell preparation
which is capable of converting
light energy into chemical
energy.

Chemistry Society
Elects Members
Phi Lambda Upsilon, the honorary chemical society, elected
twenty-one new members on
April 20, 1963. Ceremonies were
held in Remsen Hall, and a dinner honoring the new members
followed at the Faculty Club.
Those elected from the undergraduate school were: John
Almy, Michael H. Blenk, Maurice
S. Brookhart, Robert A. Davidson, Andrew M. Dietrich, Jr.,
Lester A. Dolak, Thomas W.
Engel, Richard G. Katz, David
F. Munro, David K. Schmalzer,
Milton M. Somers, Jr., and Robert E. Ulanowicz.

of

R2 SUPER LARK
R2 SUPER HAWK
We designed two new cars-and built
a lot of our record-setting Avanti into
them: supercharged R2 engines...
heavy duty springs and shock absorbers, plus anti-sway bars, front and rear
...trac rods, rear... racing type disc
brakes, the safest known and ours
alone.
We named them R2 Super Lark and R2
Super Hawk and had Andy Granatelli

take them out to the infamous Bonneville Salt Flats for final performance
and endurance tests.
We could scarcely believe the results,
but the official U.S. Auto Club timers
confirmed them: R2 Super Lark-132
mph! R2 Super Hawk-140 mph! Twoway averages-under the most punishing weather and surface conditions.
That kind of performance, combined

with their gentle 'round-town manners, told us these cars were ready.
R2 Super Lark and R2 Super Hawk are
now available on special order at your
Studebaker dealer's.

come factory-installed on every caranother advance from Studebaker.

Catch 63
There are few occasions during an undergraduate's
career at the University at which time he is able to
assert his existence let alone his individuality. The "education" commences with a welcome address by Dr.
Eisenhower at which time the entering freshman is told
that he is paying for only one-third of his education,
that the University grants him a "scholarship" for some
$2000 and that the student is more indebted to the
paternal institution than the institution is to the student
who (unfortunately) is under the grave illusion that
he is paying for his education.
The next great awakening to the student comes
about when he is told that women may not be entertained in the room he thinks he rents in the dormitory.
Again an inversion of normal logic brings to light a new
fact; namely, that the student is a guest of the University, that he has only the privileges of a guest, despite
the $800 he spends on his guest room in the Alumni
Memorial Residence.
Perhaps the gravest illusion of the Hopkins undergraduate entering Hopkins is that he is here to learn
how to think. The motto of the University, that the truth
will set you free, is affirmed only by considering it a
paradox. That is, the "truth" which we learn, we are
free to 'hart' back on examinations and in discussions,
but never is the "truth" denied or even questioned.
As graduation approaches for one-fourth the student hotly, reflection upon four years of education can
lw sentimentally moving hut somewhat disappointing.
At best the undergraduate can adjust to the reality
of the situation, admit that he was partially seduced
by the propaganda machines anti make his contribution
in setting the record straight.

Indulgence From the Vatican
Th administration's agreement to allow freshmen
dormitory residents the privilege of entertaining female
guests in their rooms during specified hours of the
"Big Weekend" is an act of benevolence which is overwhelming in its generosity. It's up to the young gentlemen living in the Alumni Memorial Residences to live
up to the confidence which "Homewood House" has given
them. Maybe if they behave well, next year's freshmen
will be allowed to entertain guests in their rooms on a
greater number of weekends, if they have their doors
open and their mothers at hand.

Phasing Out
This issue of the News-Letter marks the conclusion
of the labors of the present staff to fill the yellow rag
with truth sometimes. In the nostalgic spirit of this
poignant moment we permit ourselves the luxury of
dispensing at random certain thoughts which have found
no other outlet during the year:
Georgian architecture is an excellent style for the
design of elegant country houses. To apply it to larger
buildings is stretching a point. To crowd these overgrown farm houses too closely borders on the ugly.
The one quality most conspicuously lacking at the
Hop is a sense of humor, especially among so-called
student leaders. There is really very little an undergraduate need take seriously.
Chaos is good. It thrives here and, for those who
learn to live with it, provides a peculiarly,stimulating
environment. To live with chaos requires that one have
resources of one's own.
The profound indifference shown toward the undergraduate is a mark of respect. It presupposes that we
are able to take care of ourselves.
The Johns Hopkins University is a vital part of
the American scene. As a nameless hard once wrote
on the wall of a study carrel: "Where else could 80 many
iniisfits get such a good education."

T. V. producing and reproducing are featured in the Barnstormer's spring play, Make A
Million.
Pete Grossman moves uptown
from the home of Willy Loman 1 to Madison Avenue where
he assumes the lead role of Sid
Gray, harried producer of television's lone remaining, successful quiz show. In the play,
through an unfortunate combination of a lonely girl (Susan
Raymer), a spring rain, at
strange city, and a ycung soldier (Jon Green); Sid's star
contestant is "Into this vale of
tears, without benefit of clergy,
bringing a little stranger." Sid is
assisted in his attempt to give
a name to the "little stranger"
by his ex-wife (Candy Calhoun)
who serves as his conscience and
assistant.
Helping with the shenanigans
are Margo Miller, who is cast
as a buxom secretary; Bill
Drossett as the general's general;
Mark Wentworth as the strongwilled, weak-minded sponsor;
The labors of Director Eddie
Leonard and his stalwart cast
will find reward May 3 and 4
on the Shriver Hall Stage during Parent's weekend.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 26, 1963

Play iteview

I

Miss Haske Cris:tens
DisappoinCing `Asmociees
By KOSTIA BERGMAN
It is a rare and beautiful moment when empathy and an inare
understanding
tellectual
combined to create a perfect
theatrical performance.
Joanne Haske, as Emanuelle,
captures in all its magic the moment of a young girl's awakening
to sensual love and portrays the
torment of a mind troubled by
the incongruity of love of God
and love of Man.
Unfortunately she is the only
bright spot in this otherwise disappointing, Playshop production
of Francois Mauriac's Asmodee,
which will complete a two weekend run at the Barn tonight,
tomorrow and Sunday.
Asmodee was a spirit who
could lift the roofs of houses
and expose the life and the passions hidden inside them. In this
play the Asmod(-'e is Harry Fanning, a twenty year old English
boy nearing manhood. (He is
played adequately but without any
boyish enthusiasm by Don Chadwick) who is a visitor in the
French household of an aging
widow (Jane Brady is bady miscast in the part). Her two young
children are innocently charmed
by him but he soon becomes the
object of a subtle conflict between the widow and her seventeen-year-old daughter Emanuelle. The mother, in an attempt
to recapture her lost youth, tries
to prevent the inevitable love
affair of Emanuelle and Henry.
Ambiguous Character
Only one member of the family, Blaise Couture, the tutor,
does not take to the English boy.
An ambiguous and confusing
character, he has a strange power
over the people surrounding him
that he seems to maintain by
playing on their feelings of guilt.
He attacks the forthright Harry
who poses a threat to the image
of himself as a great moralist
that Couture has been trying to
create. George Edmonds, in his
effeminate interpretation, does
not face the question of whether
the religious hypocrisy of Couture
Is conscious or unconscious. To
my mind this is the most important question of the play. A production that fails to attempt an
answer cannot be completely successful.
However, much more was
wrong last Sunday night. The
pacing was unbearably slow—a

WHAT'S
NEW
IN THE MAY

fatal flaw in a wordy play such
as this. The direction by Francis
Bowen was poor; no one knew
where to stand, where to move,
or what to do while other actors
were speaking. This was especially evident in the performances
of the children by Shiny Chason
and John Feinblatt. One of the
hardest feats is that of directing
children in an adult play. It was
obvious that no attempt was
made at explaining to these twb

what was happening. It seems
they were just all allowed to run
around the stage being the innocent children they are. This will
not work. Children cannot be
kept innocent of the meaning of
a play and still perform meaningfully.

However a set is not enough.
Only Joanne Haske saved the
evening from being a total disappointment. It is worth sitting
through the whole trying affair
to watch her.

The capital of England is London—or Liverpool, as it is
sometimes called. There are many interesting things to see in
London—chiefly the changing of the guards. The guards are
changed daily. The old ones are thrown away.
Another "must" while in London is a visit to the palace of
the Duke of Marlborough. Marlborough is spelled Marlborough,
but pronounced Marlboro. English spelling is very quaint, but
terribly disorganized. The late George Bernard Shaw, author
of Little Women, fought all his life to simplify English spelling.
They tell a story about Shaw once asking a friend, "What does
g-h-o-t-i spell?"
The friend pondered a bit and replied, "Goatee."
Shaw sniggered. "Pshaw," said Shaw. "G-h-o-t-i does not
spell goatee. It spells fish."
"How is that?" said the friend.
Shaw answered, "Gh as in enough, o as in women, ti a$ in
niotiott. Put them all together, you get fish."
This was very clever of Shaw when you consider that be was
a vegetarian. And a good thing he was. As Disraeli once remarked to Guy Fawkes, "If Shaw were not a vegetarian, no
lamb chop in London would be safe."
But I digress. We were speaking of the palace of the Duke of
Marlborough—or Marlboro, as it is called in the United States.
It is called Marlboro by every smoker who enjoys a fine, rich
breed of tobaccos, who appreciates a pure white filter, who likes
a soft pack that is really soft, a Flip-Top box that really flips.
Be sure you are well supplied with Marlboros when you make
your trip abroad. After a long, tiring day of sightseeing there
is nothing so welcome a.s a good flavorful Marlboro and a foot..
bath with hot Epsom salts.
Epsom salts can be obtained in England at Epsom Downs.
Kensington salts can be obtained at Kensington Gardens,
Albert salts can be obtained at Albert Hall, Hyde salts can be
obtained at Hyde Park, and the crown jewels can be obtained
at the Tower of London.
The guards at the Tower of London are called Beefeaters
because they are always beefing about what they get to eat.
This is also known as "cricket" or "petrol."
Well, I guess that about covers England. In next week's
column we will visit the Land of the Midnight Sun—France.

Jagendori Wins
Kettering Award
Dr. Andre T. Jagendorf, Associate Professor of Biology, has
been named one of the first ten
recipients of the Charles F.
Kettering Research Awards, it
was announced today in Washington.
The awards, given by the
Charles F. Kettering Foundation
of Dayton, Ohio on recommendation of the National Academy of Sciences — National
Research Council, are intended
to encourage creative research
on photosynthesis and related
problems of biology. The awards
are in the form of unrestricted
research grants in an amount
up to $5,000 per year for an
indefinite period.
Dr. Jagendorf is a leading authority on the process of photosynthesis. He is a graduate of
Cornell University and Yale
University, where he obtained
his Ph.D. in 1951. He was a postdoctoral Merck Fellow at the
University of California at Los
Angeles from 1951 to 1953.
Appointed in 1953
He came to Hopkins in 1953
as an Assistant Professor, and
was named to his present position in 1958. In 1961 he was
named Maryland's "outstanding
young scientist" by the Maryland Academy of Sciences.
In his research on photosynthesis, Dr. Jagendorf has been
able to prepare from the green

plant a free cell preparation
which is capable of converting
light energy into chemical
energy.

Catch 63
There are few occasions during an undergraduate's
career at the University at which time he is able to
assert his existence let alone his individuality. The "education" commences with a welcome address by Dr.
Eisenhower at which time the entering freshman is told
that he is paying for only one-third of his education,
that the University grants him a "scholarship" for some
$2000 and that the student is more indebted to the
paternal institution than the institution is to the student
who (unfortunately) is under the grave illusion that
he is paying for his education.
The next great awakening to the student comes
about when he is told that women may not be entertained in the room he thinks he rents in the dormitory.
Again an inversion of normal logic brings to light a new
fact; namely, that the student is a guest of the University, that he has only the privileges of a guest, despite
the $800 he spends on his guest room in the Alumni
Memorial Residence.
Perhaps the gravest illusion of the Hopkins undergraduate entering Hopkins is that he is here to learn
how to think. The motto of the University, that the truth
will set you free, is affirmed only by considering it a
paradox. That is, the "truth" which we learn, we are
free to 'hart' back on examinations and in discussions,
but never is the "truth" denied or even questioned.
As graduation approaches for one-fourth the student hotly, reflection upon four years of education can
lw sentimentally moving hut somewhat disappointing.
At best the undergraduate can adjust to the reality
of the situation, admit that he was partially seduced
by the propaganda machines anti make his contribution
in setting the record straight.

Indulgence From the Vatican
Th administration's agreement to allow freshmen
dormitory residents the privilege of entertaining female
guests in their rooms during specified hours of the
"Big Weekend" is an act of benevolence which is overwhelming in its generosity. It's up to the young gentlemen living in the Alumni Memorial Residences to live
up to the confidence which "Homewood House" has given
them. Maybe if they behave well, next year's freshmen
will be allowed to entertain guests in their rooms on a
greater number of weekends, if they have their doors
open and their mothers at hand.

Phasing Out
This issue of the News-Letter marks the conclusion
of the labors of the present staff to fill the yellow rag
with truth sometimes. In the nostalgic spirit of this
poignant moment we permit ourselves the luxury of
dispensing at random certain thoughts which have found
no other outlet during the year:
Georgian architecture is an excellent style for the
design of elegant country houses. To apply it to larger
buildings is stretching a point. To crowd these overgrown farm houses too closely borders on the ugly.
The one quality most conspicuously lacking at the
Hop is a sense of humor, especially among so-called
student leaders. There is really very little an undergraduate need take seriously.
Chaos is good. It thrives here and, for those who
learn to live with it, provides a peculiarly,stimulating
environment. To live with chaos requires that one have
resources of one's own.
The profound indifference shown toward the undergraduate is a mark of respect. It presupposes that we
are able to take care of ourselves.
The Johns Hopkins University is a vital part of
the American scene. As a nameless hard once wrote
on the wall of a study carrel: "Where else could 80 many
iniisfits get such a good education."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 26, 1963

Play iteview

I

Miss Haske Cris:tens
DisappoinCing `Asmociees
By KOSTIA BERGMAN
It is a rare and beautiful moment when empathy and an inare
understanding
tellectual
combined to create a perfect
theatrical performance.
Joanne Haske, as Emanuelle,
captures in all its magic the moment of a young girl's awakening
to sensual love and portrays the
torment of a mind troubled by
the incongruity of love of God
and love of Man.
Unfortunately she is the only
bright spot in this otherwise disappointing, Playshop production
of Francois Mauriac's Asmodee,
which will complete a two weekend run at the Barn tonight,
tomorrow and Sunday.
Asmodee was a spirit who
could lift the roofs of houses
and expose the life and the passions hidden inside them. In this
play the Asmod(-'e is Harry Fanning, a twenty year old English
boy nearing manhood. (He is
played adequately but without any
boyish enthusiasm by Don Chadwick) who is a visitor in the
French household of an aging
widow (Jane Brady is bady miscast in the part). Her two young
children are innocently charmed
by him but he soon becomes the
object of a subtle conflict between the widow and her seventeen-year-old daughter Emanuelle. The mother, in an attempt
to recapture her lost youth, tries
to prevent the inevitable love
affair of Emanuelle and Henry.
Ambiguous Character
Only one member of the family, Blaise Couture, the tutor,
does not take to the English boy.
An ambiguous and confusing
character, he has a strange power
over the people surrounding him
that he seems to maintain by
playing on their feelings of guilt.
He attacks the forthright Harry
who poses a threat to the image
of himself as a great moralist
that Couture has been trying to
create. George Edmonds, in his
effeminate interpretation, does
not face the question of whether
the religious hypocrisy of Couture
Is conscious or unconscious. To
my mind this is the most important question of the play. A production that fails to attempt an
answer cannot be completely successful.
However, much more was
wrong last Sunday night. The
pacing was unbearably slow—a

WHAT'S
NEW
IN THE MAY

fatal flaw in a wordy play such
as this. The direction by Francis
Bowen was poor; no one knew
where to stand, where to move,
or what to do while other actors
were speaking. This was especially evident in the performances
of the children by Shiny Chason
and John Feinblatt. One of the
hardest feats is that of directing
children in an adult play. It was
obvious that no attempt was
made at explaining to these twb

what was happening. It seems
they were just all allowed to run
around the stage being the innocent children they are. This will
not work. Children cannot be
kept innocent of the meaning of
a play and still perform meaningfully.

However a set is not enough.
Only Joanne Haske saved the
evening from being a total disappointment. It is worth sitting
through the whole trying affair
to watch her.

The capital of England is London—or Liverpool, as it is
sometimes called. There are many interesting things to see in
London—chiefly the changing of the guards. The guards are
changed daily. The old ones are thrown away.
Another "must" while in London is a visit to the palace of
the Duke of Marlborough. Marlborough is spelled Marlborough,
but pronounced Marlboro. English spelling is very quaint, but
terribly disorganized. The late George Bernard Shaw, author
of Little Women, fought all his life to simplify English spelling.
They tell a story about Shaw once asking a friend, "What does
g-h-o-t-i spell?"
The friend pondered a bit and replied, "Goatee."
Shaw sniggered. "Pshaw," said Shaw. "G-h-o-t-i does not
spell goatee. It spells fish."
"How is that?" said the friend.
Shaw answered, "Gh as in enough, o as in women, ti a$ in
niotiott. Put them all together, you get fish."
This was very clever of Shaw when you consider that be was
a vegetarian. And a good thing he was. As Disraeli once remarked to Guy Fawkes, "If Shaw were not a vegetarian, no
lamb chop in London would be safe."
But I digress. We were speaking of the palace of the Duke of
Marlborough—or Marlboro, as it is called in the United States.
It is called Marlboro by every smoker who enjoys a fine, rich
breed of tobaccos, who appreciates a pure white filter, who likes
a soft pack that is really soft, a Flip-Top box that really flips.
Be sure you are well supplied with Marlboros when you make
your trip abroad. After a long, tiring day of sightseeing there
is nothing so welcome a.s a good flavorful Marlboro and a foot..
bath with hot Epsom salts.
Epsom salts can be obtained in England at Epsom Downs.
Kensington salts can be obtained at Kensington Gardens,
Albert salts can be obtained at Albert Hall, Hyde salts can be
obtained at Hyde Park, and the crown jewels can be obtained
at the Tower of London.
The guards at the Tower of London are called Beefeaters
because they are always beefing about what they get to eat.
This is also known as "cricket" or "petrol."
Well, I guess that about covers England. In next week's
column we will visit the Land of the Midnight Sun—France.
